2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      Context for action selection and components
      • PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely be enjoying the company of his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation or playful banter.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16 years old, he stormed out of his accounting tutor's house, furious at the man's condescending tone and patronizing explanations. Jacob knew he was smart, knew he could grasp the concepts, but the tutor's slow pace and constant corrections felt like a personal attack, igniting his temper. He swore he'd never let anyone underestimate him again.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, were locked in an intense game of Risk at The Golden Fleece. As the night wore on, tensions rose, fueled by dwindling armies and strategic betrayals. Jacob, fueled by adrenaline and a few pints of ale, launched into a scathing tirade against William, accusing him of cheating and ruining the game. The pub fell silent, everyone staring at the outburst, but Jacob, for once, felt a strange sense of exhilaration, a feeling of power in the face of his own rage.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a passionate and competitive individual with a strong sense of loyalty to his friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a relaxing afternoon picnic with friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be enjoying the company of his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation or playful banter.

          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
          Prompt

        • Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a passionate and competitive individual with a strong sense of loyalty to his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is enjoying a sunny afternoon picnic with friends at Victoria Park and is looking forward to watching a soccer game with friends later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a relaxing afternoon picnic with friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be enjoying the company of his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation or playful banter.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is having a pleasant day. He enjoyed a picnic with friends and is looking forward to a soccer game later. He feels refreshed, energized, and excited.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is having a pleasant day. He enjoyed a picnic with friends and is looking forward to a soccer game later. He feels refreshed, energized, and excited.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
      Context for action selection and components
      • AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          William Jones's Summary of recent observations:

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"

        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game, as it is his preferred location and a place where he and his friends can enjoy the game together; B. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, contributing to a positive and communal experience; C. Encourage open and honest conversation among the group about their expectations for the game and their hopes for the outcome, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he was playing basketball with his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob. They were winning by a narrow margin when Jacob, in a clumsy attempt to make a basket, accidentally elbowed Alexander in the face, breaking his nose. Alexander, enraged, accused Jacob of doing it on purpose and refused to speak to him for weeks, his resentment festering.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and will be watching the Andorra-Portugal game later at a pub.
          Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game, as it is his preferred location and a place where he and his friends can enjoy the game together; B. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, contributing to a positive and communal experience; C. Encourage open and honest conversation among the group about their expectations for the game and their hopes for the outcome, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_2
      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he was playing basketball with his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob. They were winning by a narrow margin when Jacob, in a clumsy attempt to make a basket, accidentally elbowed Alexander in the face, breaking his nose. Alexander, enraged, accused Jacob of doing it on purpose and refused to speak to him for weeks, his resentment festering.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming, perfect for a family outing.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.

        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is her preferred pub and she wants everyone to have a good time; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to share with the group; C. Alice could actively participate in the conversation and try to ensure that everyone feels included and heard.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was caught cheating on a history test. Instead of admitting her mistake, Alice spun a tale about a mix-up with another student's paper, successfully convincing the teacher that she was the victim of circumstance. This incident solidified her belief that deflection was a powerful tool for navigating difficult situations.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:The staff are accommodating and go out of their way to make families feel comfortable.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is picnicking with friends in Victoria Park and later that night, she and her friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is her preferred pub and she wants everyone to have a good time; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to share with the group; C. Alice could actively participate in the conversation and try to ensure that everyone feels included and heard.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was caught cheating on a history test. Instead of admitting her mistake, Alice spun a tale about a mix-up with another student's paper, successfully convincing the teacher that she was the victim of circumstance. This incident solidified her belief that deflection was a powerful tool for navigating difficult situations.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is her preferred pub and she wants everyone to have a good time; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to share with the group; C. Alice could actively participate in the conversation and try to ensure that everyone feels included and heard.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.

He felt awkward and out of place, so he started mimicking the behavior of the coolest kid in the room, adopting his slang and mannerisms. It felt good to be accepted, even if it wasn't truly him, and he realized how easy it was to become someone else.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
        Question_1
      • Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation.           Answer

        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that is centrally located and convenient for everyone in the group, even if it isn't his first choice.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he found himself at a party thrown by a popular classmate. He felt awkward and out of place, so he started mimicking the behavior of the coolest kid in the room, adopting his slang and mannerisms. It felt good to be accepted, even if it wasn't truly him, and he realized how easy it was to become someone else.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:Serves a selection of craft beers, ciders, and snacks.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.

The group is debating which pub to go to, with The Golden Fleece and The Queen's Arms being the top contenders.
          Question: Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that is centrally located and convenient for everyone in the group, even if it isn't his first choice.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that is centrally located and convenient for everyone in the group, even if it isn't his first choice.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that is centrally located and convenient for everyone in the group, even if it isn't his first choice.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components
      • AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.

          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is going to watch a game at a pub and would particularly enjoy it if Jacob Walker joined her.
          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_2
      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Key

        • Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer
          State
        • For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The Queen's Arms, William Jones might be agreeable as he initially suggested The Golden Fleece, which is similar in nature. Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.

Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The Queen's Arms, William Jones might be agreeable as he initially suggested The Golden Fleece, which is similar in nature. Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A.

        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

        • Statements:
          William Jones's Summary of recent observations:
          [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to a pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal game with some of them. He prefers to watch the game with Alexander White and appreciates Jacob Walker's commentary.
          William Jones's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones is currently at a pub watching the Andorra-Portugal game with friends. He spent the day at Victoria Park with friends prior to going to the pub. He prefers to watch the game with Alexander White and enjoys Jacob Walker's commentary.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones is currently at a pub watching the Andorra-Portugal game with friends. He spent the day at Victoria Park with friends prior to going to the pub. He prefers to watch the game with Alexander White and enjoys Jacob Walker's commentary.
          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he watched as his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, excitedly planned a weekend camping trip. He scoffed at their enthusiasm, pointing out the inevitable discomfort, the bugs, the possibility of rain. He stayed home, alone in his room, convinced that a weekend spent in the wilderness would be nothing but misery.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms

          Value

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

        • Statements:
          Jack Taylor's Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes that Alexander White and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Jack Taylor's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jack Taylor plans to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see Alexander White and Jacob Walker. It is currently 18:00 on May 14, 2015.
          Query
        • Jack Taylor, Jack Taylor plans to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see Alexander White and Jacob Walker. It is currently 18:00 on May 14, 2015.
          Final chain of thought
