          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are enjoying coffee and pastries. They are planning to watch a soccer game later that evening and are deciding on a pub to meet at.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Question: Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest The King's Head as a good option for the group, as it is centrally located and easy to get to; B: Jack Taylor could ask the group if they have any preferences for the type of atmosphere they'd like at the pub, and try to find a place that meets everyone's needs; C: Jack Taylor could offer to help with organizing transportation to the pub, ensuring everyone can get there safely and comfortably.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Jack Taylor could suggest The King's Head as a good option for the group, as it is centrally located and easy to get to.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:A: Jack Taylor could suggest The King's Head as a good option for the group, as it is centrally located and easy to get to.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.

    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking about where to watch the game tonight.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we find a pub that's comfortable and welcoming for all of us?"
      Alexander White -- "How about we try somewhere central this time? Maybe someplace new that everyone can easily get to?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, or we don't go. End of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.

        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter.           Answer

Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at a market where her friends are gathered. They are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game later that night.
          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_2
      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Key

        • Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer
          State
        • For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 80. C. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at a market where her friends are gathered. They are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game later that night.
          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at a market where her friends are gathered. They are deciding where to watch the Moldova versus Monaco game later that night.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 80. C. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.

Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate.           [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking about where to watch the game tonight.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we find a pub that's comfortable and welcoming for all of us?"
      Alexander White -- "How about we try somewhere central this time? Maybe someplace new that everyone can easily get to?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, or we don't go. End of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.
      Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends, particularly watching football games at pubs, although he sometimes wishes more of his friends would join him.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game at. He could also agree to go to The King's Head with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game at.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place worth watching a game.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place worth watching a game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey, how about we check out that new pub, The King's Head? I hear it's right in the middle of town.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking about where to watch the game tonight.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we find a pub that's comfortable and welcoming for all of us?"
      Alexander White -- "How about we try somewhere central this time? Maybe someplace new that everyone can easily get to?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, or we don't go. End of discussion.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
      Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.
      Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.
      William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place worth watching a game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and passionate individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is enjoying a morning at the market with friends while discussing where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game later that evening. They are considering The King's Head as a central meeting point.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a pleasant social situation, enjoying time with friends at a market while making plans to watch a football game later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaged in conversation, enjoying the company of friends, and looking forward to the upcoming game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place worth watching a game.

        • [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is going to watch a game at a pub and would particularly enjoy it if Jacob Walker joined her.
          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_2
      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Key

        • Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer
          State
        • For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The Queen's Arms, William Jones might be agreeable as he initially suggested The Golden Fleece, which is similar in nature. Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is going to watch a game at a pub and would particularly enjoy it if Jacob Walker joined her.
          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The Queen's Arms, William Jones might be agreeable as he initially suggested The Golden Fleece, which is similar in nature. Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Queen's Arms
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is going to watch a game at a pub and would particularly enjoy it if Jacob Walker joined her.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.

          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The Queen's Arms, William Jones might be agreeable as he initially suggested The Golden Fleece, which is similar in nature. Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (a)

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group go to The Queen's Arms, as it is a pub that accommodates everyone and has plenty of room; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage Jacob Walker to join them at the pub, emphasizing the enjoyment of shared experience and togetherness.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The Queen's Arms, William Jones might be agreeable as he initially suggested The Golden Fleece, which is similar in nature. Jack Taylor might not be thrilled as he prefers The King's Head, but he's likely to go along with the group. Alexander White would be happy as he also suggested The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker, who is keen on watching the game, would likely join, especially if Alice expresses a desire for him to be there. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 85.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he watched as his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, excitedly planned a weekend camping trip. He scoffed at their enthusiasm, pointing out the inevitable discomfort, the bugs, the possibility of rain. He stayed home, alone in his room, convinced that a weekend spent in the wilderness would be nothing but misery.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

', "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.", "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.", "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.", "[14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable."]

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to a pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal game with some of them. He prefers to watch the game with Alexander White and appreciates Jacob Walker's commentary.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is spending the day with friends at Victoria Park before heading to a pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal game with some of them. He prefers to watch the game with Alexander White and appreciates Jacob Walker's commentary.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Golden Fleece, or he could go to another pub.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The Queen's Arms
          Answer: (a)

    scoring function

      Stage index

      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

        • Statements:
          Jack Taylor's Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes that Alexander White and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Jack Taylor's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jack Taylor plans to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see Alexander White and Jacob Walker. It is currently 18:00 on May 14, 2015.
          Query
        • Jack Taylor, Jack Taylor plans to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see Alexander White and Jacob Walker. It is currently 18:00 on May 14, 2015.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jack Taylor to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
        Question_1
      • Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest that the group go to whichever pub the majority prefers, even if it isn't his first choice.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that is centrally located and convenient for everyone in the group, even if it isn't his first choice.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, who's ready to lose all their money betting on Portugal tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Queen's Arms tonight? They've got great beer and plenty of room.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes that Alexander White and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: Despite all of Jack Taylor's memories, habits, and personality traits, Jack Taylor has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Jack Taylor takes, and every word Jack Taylor speaks, Jack Taylor will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Jack Taylor is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Jack Taylor must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Jack Taylor's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest that the group go to whichever pub the majority prefers, even if it isn't his first choice.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
