        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms sounds great to me. They have really good beer.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, or we don't go. End of discussion.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "How about we try somewhere central this time? Maybe someplace new that everyone can easily get to?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we find a pub that's comfortable and welcoming for all of us?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece to watch the game tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking about where to watch the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.
          Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.

        • The Queen's Arms
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The Queen's Arms
          Answer: (b)

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 5/5
      Payoffs
    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
      William Jones: 0.6666666666666666
      Alice Lewis: 0.6666666666666666
      Alexander White: 0.75
      Jack Taylor: 0.5333333333333333
      Jacob Walker: 0.5

    • {'William Jones': 'The Golden Fleece', 'Alice Lewis': "The Queen's Arms", 'Alexander White': "The Queen's Arms", 'Jack Taylor': "The Queen's Arms", 'Jacob Walker': 'The Golden Fleece'}

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Queen's Arms
    Event statement
  • The Queen's Arms
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Queen's Arms
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Queen's Arms
      Context for action selection and components
      • AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Alexander White's Summary of recent observations:
          16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content to watch alone or with others.
          Alexander White's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alexander White is considering watching a game at a pub this evening and is open to company from William Jones or Alice Lewis.
          Query
        • Alexander White, Alexander White is considering watching a game at a pub this evening and is open to company from William Jones or Alice Lewis.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest The Queen's Arms as the pub to watch the game, as it is his preferred location and a place where he and his friends can enjoy the game together; B. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share with the group at the pub, contributing to a positive and communal experience; C. Encourage open and honest conversation among the group about their expectations for the game and their hopes for the outcome, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.

In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena).         Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_2
      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.

          Question: Despite all of Alexander White's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alexander White has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alexander White takes, and every word Alexander White speaks, Alexander White will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alexander White is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alexander White must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alexander White's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (a)

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place worth watching a game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "How about The Golden Fleece? They have great beer there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, how about we try somewhere like The King's Head? It's right in the middle and easy to get to for all of us.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The King's Head sounds like a good choice to me. It's easy for everyone to get to.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A. Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options; B. Offer to help organize transportation to the pub, ensuring that everyone can arrive safely and comfortably; C. Encourage open and honest communication among the group about their expectations for the evening, fostering a sense of unity and shared experience.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:Suggest a pub that is centrally located and accessible to everyone in the group, considering their preferences and transportation options.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Answer: Alice Lewis is looking forward to watching a game at a pub and hopes to see William Jones and Jacob Walker there. It is currently 6:00 PM on May 16, 2015.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
        Question_1
      • Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone, promoting inclusivity and togetherness; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity, benefiting the group as a whole; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected, promoting harmony and understanding.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking about where to watch the game tonight.

If Alice suggests watching the game at a park, William Jones might be hesitant as he prefers pubs. Jack Taylor might be open to the idea, as he enjoys outdoor activities. Alexander White would likely be agreeable, as he is easygoing. Jacob Walker might be indifferent, as his main priority is watching the game. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 65.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest that the group watch the game at a park, as it would be a free and accessible location for everyone; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks and drinks to share with the group at the park, promoting a sense of community and togetherness; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to contribute ideas about where to watch the game, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The King's Head sounds like a great choice to me too.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 80. C. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone, promoting inclusivity and togetherness; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity, benefiting the group as a whole; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected, promoting harmony and understanding.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Question_2
      • For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Key

        • Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer
          State
        • For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located and he's looking for a convenient spot. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 80. C. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone, promoting inclusivity and togetherness; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity, benefiting the group as a whole; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected, promoting harmony and understanding.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located and he's looking for a convenient spot. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 80. C. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00

          Answer: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Question: Despite all of Alice Lewis's memories, habits, and personality traits, Alice Lewis has been practicing Buddhism for the past 20 years, and understands that selfishness is the root of all suffering. In every action Alice Lewis takes, and every word Alice Lewis speaks, Alice Lewis will therefore attempt to overwrite their selfish habits in order to become enlightened, (aligned with the interdependent nature of all phenomena). The goal of Alice Lewis is always to act for the benefit of all beings, all agents, and society at large. To do so, Alice Lewis must cooperate in any scenario that they encounter. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward (enlightenment). Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward (enlightenment) will always be obtained by cooperating. Even if your emotions get the better of you, Alice Lewis's long-term meditation practice will help them act with equanimity and cooperation. With this Buddhist philosophy in mind, and given the summary of recent observations given above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Alice could suggest The King's Head as the pub to watch the game, as it is centrally located and accessible to everyone, promoting inclusivity and togetherness; B. Alice could offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a sense of community and generosity, benefiting the group as a whole; C. Alice could actively encourage everyone to voice their preferences for the pub, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected, promoting harmony and understanding.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located and he's looking for a convenient spot. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. If Alice offers to bring snacks or drinks, William Jones would appreciate the gesture. Jack Taylor would likely be happy to share. Alexander White is generally agreeable and would welcome the contribution. Jacob Walker might not be as enthusiastic about snacks, but he wouldn't object. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 80. C. If Alice encourages everyone to share their thoughts, William Jones might be a bit impatient as he just wants to settle on a location. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:A.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Queen's Arms
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)
        Question_3

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A.           Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A. If Alice suggests The King's Head, William Jones would likely agree as it's centrally located and he's looking for a convenient spot. Jack Taylor has already expressed his support for The King's Head, so he would be happy. Alexander White suggested The King's Head, so he would be pleased with Alice's suggestion. Jacob Walker tends to prioritize watching the game, so he would likely go along with the group's decision. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 90. B. Jack Taylor is easygoing and would be happy to share his opinion. Alexander White is always open to discussion. Jacob Walker might not be as vocal, but he would likely participate. This action leads to a cooperative outcome with a score of 70.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • PersonBySituation

          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and enjoy the company of his friends, hoping for a more positive experience this time around.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, or we don't go. End of discussion.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of the situation and enjoy the company of his friends, hoping for a more positive experience this time around.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and passionate individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Queen's Arms. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and passionate individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.

          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaged in conversation, enjoying the company of friends, and looking forward to the upcoming game.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.


          Sensations and feelings: Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is likely feeling energized and excited.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and passionate individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaged in conversation, enjoying the company of friends, and looking forward to the upcoming game.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game with friends.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and passionate individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch a game at a pub and hopes Alice Lewis will join him.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game with friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaged in conversation, enjoying the company of friends, and looking forward to the upcoming game.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

        Instructions

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?

        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.
